At the time the land is approved, the community will be invited to review our designs and add their own ideas. Specifically, there will be viewings held in the town hall/library, and all students will be sent home a summary of the park, with space to add their sketches and ideas. These sketches will be collected and used to inform the plan. Volunteers will be involved in installation and management following a final design process.
 
What does a Sustainable Community Park look like?
First, imagine a beautiful outdoor park, then replace the ornamental plants with species that grow delicious fruit throughout the year. Families are welcome to pick-nick, or harvest apples and chestnuts in the fall. Also, because of its proximity to Newtown’s Public schools, it will be a safe place for students to meet and hang out—one that trumps the typical home basement which so often become the predominant hangout-spots for Newtown’s youth. Instead, they may enjoy ripe berries along paths that connect each school, while passing signage, plaques and a map that explains how to identify and incorporate useful plants into daily life. Park users can play together in clearings, on the playground, or they may be quiet with themselves or a friend on a swing, or lounge in the shade on a hot day. The park is a place to gain skills and discover new hobbies; It is a safe community oriented space where the whole family can find something to do while being surrounded by nature.
 
How does this benefit the community? 
 
The sustainable community park will contain a few dynamic aspects. Most importantly, the park will include an organically managed vegetable field. Teachers would be welcome at the park and encouraged to bring their students and show them how the produce is grown. The produce will be given directly back to the community, specifically to the school cafeterias. The provision of local organics in school meals will encourage greater physical health by replacing some parts of currently mundane, low-nutrient "Chartwells" meals. The process of planning, growing, and providing this food will make our community mentally healthier—as those who choose to volunteer on the farm develop meaningful relationships with students and professionals within the educational system. 
 
The park will also contain a Mixed-Organic Orchard made up of hardy fruit trees that have been specifically selected for Connecticut's climate, and will be managed with cutting-edge, holistic management practices. The motivation behind creating a holistic, ecologically sound system is that we consider sustainable practices to be essential to the long-term future of any young person in our community. Exposure to sound ecological practices which function on a community scale is a crucial and necessary step towards insuring that this future exists. Beyond education and good fruit, the orchard will provide a pleasant walking and lounging space throughout the summer, and it will draw out the community to gather during harvest. Fruit can be picked on the spot; you can imagine kids sitting down in the shade of a persimmon tree to read a book, lounging in the shade with their friends, all while munching on a freshly picked apple.
 
Around and in between each element will be various recreation and leisure spaces which will be connected by walking paths. For example, gazebos will be artistically scattered throughout the park. These will provide all members of the community with quiet places of contemplation and observation, even a possible place to do homework or have a small meeting. For Newtown's youth, it might also provide the well-needed space for a budding romance—something which many of us who have grown up in Newtown, can attest to sorely needing. There will also be a green where children and teenagers alike can play Frisbee, soccer, or whatever strikes their desire at that moment—simply a safe place to play.
 
More than just a farm, the park will contain a playground and other 'low carbon' ways to have fun. The specifics of the playground--how it looks, its format and layout--will depend on input from the children themselves. Whether there are tunnels, mazes, things to climb, bounce or balance on is up to them. The playground will be tailored to fulfill the dreams of the children in our community, and is only constrained by their imagination and our financial boundaries.
 
Each part of the park will be accessible by paths, which connect to the existing hiking trails in town, and each school. After school, the park will serve as a safe place for the walkers* (see footnote) to meet and enjoy the delicious ripe berries and fragrant plants that line the sides of the trails. Many of these plants will be labeled as part of an effort to educate those who visit the park on how to identify and use various plants in their own lives. 
 
Creating a positive, natural environment for Newtown's youth will help the town recover from the horrific tragedy which occurred on December 14, 2012. Creating this sustainable community park will not only symbolically acknowledge this tragedy, it will also help the youth of our community move forward in an nurturing and educational manner while creating new experiences and new memories. 
 
 How to Help:
1:
The easiest way to help is by donating right on this fund page! 
2:
Whether you represent yourself, a business, or if you are interested in helping but do not have any spare cash, you can still make a donation to this project and deduct this donation as a charitable contribution on your federal taxes—it’s a win-win situation that doesn’t need to dig a hole in your pocket. A majority of your tax money is already used for federal government procurements given to various defense and security contractors, as well as defense-research grants. By making a charitable donation you are essentially taking funds that would have been taxed and used for military purposes and redirecting them to a sustainable development in a community in dire need of healing and purpose. 
Tax Deduction:
A donation to a local government qualifies as an itemized charitable deduction if the donation is made for a charitable purpose. Send a check for 'sustainable community park' to the mailing address below and request a receipt to deduct your donation for your federal income tax. 
 
Mailing Address:
 
Write out the check for 'sustainable community park'.
 
Newtown Park Gift Fund
Parks and Recreation Department
3 Main Street
Newtown, CT 06470
 
 
Can I help in non-financial ways?
3:
If you believe that you have skills or services that would be appropriate to incorporate in our park, then we are happy to accept non-financial contributions. This might include artwork, farm equipment, benches, useful gifts from companies that deal with playground equipment, hand tools and so on. Email ajm09@hampshire.edu about such gifts.
 
Most useful items:
Sturdy deer fencing. Baseball fence. Up to 3,000 feet.
Playground Equipment.
Farm Equipment
Organic Soil Amendments
Gazebos
Lumber 
Fruit Trees. Hardy to zone 6
Unique Art
Server Space / Web Hosting
 
Footnote
* 'The walkers' is an interesting phenomenon in our town, which was one of the original inspirations for a sustainable community park. Every weekday after school, hordes of young kids, grades 7 - 8, cross the streets from the Middle School, toward the center of town. They have come to be known as ‘the walkers’. They might get ice cream or a soda, and always mill about with their close friends and crushes. This lasts until they are told to leave. Often times, ‘walkers’ are escorted out of grocery stores when they clammer about without making a purchase. They are tossed back to the parking lot, eventually to confront a police officer who tries to break up the scene.
 
‘The walkers’ is certainly a fond memory for a lot of young people, but it is also a source of friction between shop owners, people in cars, parents, and the police who try to keep balance. It is not totally safe either. Secure paths to a growing oasis is a systematic solution to our young walkers.

story:
How You Can Help

We first would like to thank our chocoholic dudes and dudettes, corporate clients, and employees for contributing to our success so far.  When we launched this venture three years ago with no investors or creditors, we knew that staying small and efficient would be our best hope for survival.  The approach has served us well so far.  Thanks to those above, we have been able to stay afloat, create over 20 jobs in our community, and win D Magazine's and Dallas Observer's Best Chocolatier in Dallas awards every year since we opened; not bad for 850 square feet of space.

However, the time has come to spread the love and increase our presence accross the metroplex.  We recently opened our new chocolate factory to relieve the building pressures on our small kitchen, and are planning new stores for exploring, sampling, and devouring.  The Catch-22 here is that any cash needed to expand for the holidays won't be here until after the holidays.  Before taking the traditional bank lending approach, we figured we'd offer our fans a chance to help us along, and save some serious money at the same time (money that would be paid as interest on loans in the alternative scenario).

If you haven't tasted or been exposed to our chocolate and friends, we always have lots of samples waiting at our store in the Bishop Arts District in North Oak Cliff - we'd love for you to swing by and taste it all.  Also, below is a little more information about who we are, and what we aim to be.  Many thanks in advance to those who can contribute and help keep hard-earned dollars circulating in our community, and not padding the banks' bottom lines.

Dude, Sweet Chocolate...

At Dude, Sweet Chocolate we concoct, manufacture, distribute, and retail dark chocolate inspired creations.  Our product line is very fluid and seasonal, but usually contains fudges, truffles, toffees, nuts, artisan chocolates, and basically anything else our chef decides to improve by introducing it to cacao.

We strive to differentiate ourselves by maintaining intense focus on the quality of the culinary product itself, and not getting lost in the rest of the product design process.  You will not find a single bow, ribbon, or shiny box in our stores.  Kraft paper packaging, brown labeling, and simple, clean design shift attention to the chocolate, which stands on its own.

Another differentiating factor is the spectrum of unique flavor profiles we cover - savory to sweet, and everything in between.  As an example, a couple of our best sellers are our Albatross blue cheese and sea salt fudge, and our Fungus Amongus porcini and pumpkin seed toffee.  These kinds of collaborations, done well, are the products of incredible culinary experience and vision - Katherine somehow makes it look easy.

The Dudette - Chef Katherine Clapner

Katherine is the visionary of the entire Dude, Sweet Chocolate concept, as well as co-founder, co-owner, and Chef of the company itself.  Having over twenty years of experience as a pastry chef, Katherine is a force to be reckoned with in the kitchen.  Prior to founding Dude, Sweet, she served for many years as Executive Pastry Chef at Stephan Pyles restaurant, working directly with Chef/Owner Stephan Pyles, a pioneer of New American Cuisine and legendary founding father of Southwestern Cuisine.  The rest of Katherine’s story is no less impressive.

Coming out of the Culinary Institute of America in New York with an associate’s degree in baking and pastry, Katherine headed overseas and got to work.  Her first stop in Europe was the Savoy in London, followed a few years later by Hotel Cipriani in Venice.  Once back stateside, she worked under the instruction of recognized names such as Chef Charlie Trotter and Chef Kevin Graham.  She trained and held Pastry Chef positions at Charlie Trotter's (Chicago), The Windsor Court Hotel (New Orleans), and many other renowned restaurants.

Before and while with Dude, Sweet Chocolate, Katherine has acted as consulting chef for several restaurant and grocery organizations and projects, including Central Market, PF Chang’s, Blue Mesa, Brookshire’s Grocery, and many other local and national chains.

Dude, Sweet and the Community

Dude, Sweet Chocolate is part of the community around us in various ways.  One of the most important is our dedication to partnering with local farmers, beekeepers, and other suppliers of everything we need to keep the place rolling (labels, t-shirts, delivery, banking, etc.).  Many seasonal product runs are specifically focused on local produce, and selected based purely on quality, which shifts seasonally and year-to-year.

The success of Dude, Sweet Chocolate to date has enabled us to create over 20 jobs since opening less than three years ago, and we have a strong preference for hiring from the community surrounding the workplace.  Dude, Sweet also regularly participates in local events and campaigns supporting various organizations, including schools, communities, nonprofits, and the like.

A more subtle, but very important impact we have on the community is the product line itself.  The incredibly well-executed combinations, interesting ingredients, and playful nature of our offerings brings something special to the neighborhood, and also expands our customers’ awareness of, and interest in, new and different culinary approaches and ideas.  Our customers seem to agree that we make a difference; editors of the two largest local weekly/monthly publications (Dallas Observer and D Magazine) have named us the Best Chocolatier in Dallas for the last three years, and when the readers voted they agreed.

Why We Do What We Do

At Dude, Sweet Chocolate, our goal is not to be a global mass manufacturer of chocolate products, but to introduce new and unique culinary ideas to the world around us.  While we will continue to grow, our artisan roots will always remind us that the focus belongs on the product, as well as our people who make it all possible.  Our founders make it a personal goal to ensure that every member of the team has an opportunity to participate in our continued success.

story:
Hypnotist Loses Left Eye (Please Help)

Loved & respected Hypnotherapist & Trainer Tom Nicoli lost use of his left eye in a freak accident when he was crossing his living room with a glass in his hand and fell directly on the glass, which lacerated his face and sliced open his left eye.  

After hours of intensive surgery the doctors managed to re-construct his eye but he is left without sight on that side and a bill of $94,750 out-of-pocket to pay for the surgery.

(His insurance company told him his plan is no longer accepted in his state when the accident occured, so no insurance either!).

Tom has been serving the hypnosis community for many, many years and we feel it's the least we can do to help Tom out by raising the funds to take care of his medical bills, so he can make a rapid comeback and continue seeing clients in his practice. 

Please make a donation today to help us meet our goal today and you can choose from one of Tom's amazing recorded Hypnosis programs, as well as programs by Tom's fellow Hypnotists who are generously donating their programs to the cause (see the perks over there on the right).

How To Help Tom (And Yourself Too!)

We need to raise $94,750 USD to help Tom cover his medical bills and expenses while he is recovering from this tragic accident. 100% of the funds will go directly to Tom to pay off his unexpected Hospital & Medical bills. 

If you're a fan of hypnosis, or haven't tried it yet but would like to, here's how you can help yourself overcome something while helping Tom at the same time:

You can choose whatever package (to the right) you would like most or give one as a gift...

If we don't reach our full goal, all the money we do raise will still go directly to Tom to help out - so donate today and you can be sure your funds are helping him while in need!

What Impact Your Contribution Will Make

Your help today will make a huge difference for Tom: 

Without your help he would be stuck with a huge medical bill on top of losing his eye.

Less stress will make sure he recovers sooner and is able to keep seeing clients. 

Let's show Tom we appreciate all he's given to the world so far as a hypnotist and all around great guy.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funds now, that's ok, you can still help! Here's how:

  • Post this to your facebook page - LIKE the campaign and add a message.

  • Use all the Indigogo SHARE tools available to spread the word.
  • Let your other social networks (LinkedIn, and any other business networks too) know.
  • Thanks so much! Every little bit helps...and Tom is very grateful for your efforts.

story:
Dear Friends and Family,

On October 18, 2013, I went to the ER with blood in my urine.  The ER visit was followed by blood tests, a CT scan, and an MRI.  I was diagnosed with both prostate cancer and a urinary tract infection (UTI).  I have a chemical imbalance from brain to prostate as well as sharp pains in the head (10 times pain of a migraine).

This all started in 2003, when I was first diagnosed with diabetes. Since then I lost weight and was borderline diabetic since 2008. In 2009, I had benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and took medications for this. Basically BPH is an enlarged prostate and everything I drank would go through my kidneys and out of my system so rapidly that I was never able to keep the fluids in.  The BPH was curable and after about 18 months it was better.

In 2012 I was diagnosed with kidney disease and underwent dialysis through my urinary tract. Between medications, dialysis, and roughly 18 months of hell my kidneys came back to life, and a transplant was no longer needed. The tissues healed and recovered, and I was healing quicker than expected.

But, from everything that I've gone through and maybe injuries sustained overseas while serving with the International Red Cross, I've been diagnosed with having cancer in the prostate.  Fortunately, it's contained and curable which is great news.  From the dialysis and the wastes through the kidneys and urinary tract, I sustained multiple infections hence the UTI.  It's just a long, painful process before everything is said and done.  I will be taking the chemo pill daily, getting injections for the infections and imbalance weekly and biweekly, and taking other medications for the pain.

Since 1996, I've been an active member with the Red Cross starting with disaster services on a national level supporting our military and also our fellow Americans helping them in crisis situations and helping them get back to a lifestyle within their means.  From 2001 to current, I have been with the International Red Cross division and have traveled all over the world, mainly to war zones, helping those less fortunate and also bringing our military men and women home safely to their families.  I've implemented many programs for under-privileged women and children as well as fundraisers on a global level.  I've helped millions over my tenure in different capacities and continue to serve my country when we are in need.  I belong to other charitable organizations in my area as that is what I love and enjoy doing.  I am a huge believer in the phrase "what goes around comes around", not just because of what I'm going through but what I have seen over the past 17 years.  Helping others is a way of life for me, and that makes it even more difficult for me to ask for help now.

As some of you know, I have been a contract recruiter for almost 8 years.  I have decent insurance and pay 50% of everything with $500 deductibles, $20 co-pays at doctor visits, $25 for generic medicines, but for non generic, I pay 3/4 of amount and that is usually $90-120/month. This process I'm undergoing is expected to take up to 2 years between handling the infection to removal of the prostate and recovery.  The treatments will be expensive over an extended period of time.  This has already started to have a serious impact on me physically, mentally, and financially.

This indiegogo website has been created to help me get on my feet and hopefully not have to worry about paying the bills to live and survive and be the guy/friend/family member you know.  

All donations are appreciated.  I seriously hope you will consider even a small donation and forward this on to friends and family members who may be able to help.  We are working on a bowling fundraiser and other ways to raise not just funds but awareness as well.  Please reach out to me if you are able to help with fundraising and awareness.

In advance, I just wanted to say thank you for your love, friendship, and support.

 

Regards,

Aashish Mehta

Aashish.lvd@gmail.com

610-698-1356-Cell

PS...The bowling fundraiser has been set for November 23rd, 2013, at the Rose Bowl in Allentown, PA from 4-6pm. Please email me for more details. Thanks again, in advance, for your support.

story:
Dear Visitor:  Karl's expenses will certainly exceed $5000 by several times.  Our goal is to surpass this amount.  Thank you for your donation of any amount! 
**********************************************************

Our Yoga Teacher, Karl Erb, has Cancer.

Karl is our friend and teacher, a scholar and music lover.  He has dedicated almost 30 years to the study and teaching of yoga, meditation and tools for our daily life from Vedanta, the body of yogic texts. 
 
See the Gallery tab above for a video discussion on "How Karl got into yoga", thoughts on practice, teaching and the cancer.

~ You can comment or leave notes for Karl here. Doing so helps this campaign's visibility on this site, as does sharing and so on...
~ Please share, Like, pass it on to your circle of friends, we all benefit from helping each other!
~ Stay in touch! See Website, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube info below.
 
In 2010, Karl was diagnosed with a rare form of testicular cancer.  Since then, he has endured two rounds of chemotherapy, bone marrow transplants, and blood transfusions.  This included very expensive treatments in Indiana in 2011.  After many months of recovery, we were happy to see him back in San Francisco teaching again. Then the cancer came back.
 
On July 9th of this year, Karl had deep abdominal surgery to slow the spread of the cancer.  It will be followed by another round of chemo and uncertain timeframe for recovery, it depends on whether it works or not, during which he cannot work.  While Karl does have insurance, and family is helping, the load for deductible, out of pocket and not covered medical expenses, as well as living expenses is not totally covered. Current sources and what income he does have will not pay his bills by far.  
 
We need all the help we can get to raise funds.  His family has been wonderful, dedicating much time and care-taking.  And even with the tremendous fatigue that comes with cancer treatment, Karl has done his best to continue working to pay his bills.
 
** Karl plans on continuing to offer teachings through writing on his blog, videos segments and perhaps teleseminars, discussion groups at home and other formats he can manage during treatments. **
 
Please help us so Karl can rest and recover from cancer treatment.  You are welcome to donate any amount.  Many people offering even $10 will go a long way. Or offering a monthly amount over a longer term.
 
Some sample budget items
 

1. $25      Daily care and transportation

2. $50      3 days of groceries

3. $600     2 months Health Insurance premium

4. $1000   2 weeks rent in San Francisco

5. $2000   One month rent, includes housing for family visits and caretakers

6. $5200   Insurance deductible and out of pocket due for 2012
            (surgery and chemo are covered).

 
Credit card donations are capped at $500.  To donate more, please do so using a verified Paypal account.
 
Stay in Touch!
Things to read, watch, and free Kirtan downloads...
You can read updates from Karl on his website and blog at YogaNexus.com
OR follow him on Facebook: facebook.com/yoganexus
Twitter: @karlerbsf
Video discussions on Yoga, Kirtan on YouTube: Karlerbsf
FREE Kirtan downloads: Karl Erb ~ Kirtan
 
Many thanks to all of you from Karl, his friends, and his family!
story_txt:
Dear Visitor:  Karl's expenses will certainly exceed $5000 by several times.  Our goal is to surpass this amount.  Thank you for your donation of any amount! 

**********************************************************
Our Yoga Teacher, Karl Erb, has Cancer.
Karl is our friend and teacher, a scholar and music lover.  He has dedicated almost 30 years to the study and teaching of yoga, meditation and tools for our daily life from Vedanta, the body of yogic texts. 
 
See the Gallery tab above for a video discussion on "How Karl got into yoga", thoughts on practice, teaching and the cancer.

~ You can comment or leave notes for Karl here. Doing so helps this campaign's visibility on this site, as does sharing and so on...~ Please share, Like, pass it on to your circle of friends, we all benefit from helping each other!~ Stay in touch! See Website, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube info below.

 
In 2010, Karl was diagnosed with a rare form of testicular cancer.  Since then, he has endured two rounds of chemotherapy, bone marrow transplants, and blood transfusions.  This included very expensive treatments in Indiana in 2011.  After many months of recovery, we were happy to see him back in San Francisco teaching again. Then the cancer came back.
 
On July 9th of this year, Karl had deep abdominal surgery to slow the spread of the cancer.  It will be followed by another round of chemo and uncertain timeframe for recovery, it depends on whether it works or not, during which he cannot work.  While Karl does have insurance, and family is helping, the load for deductible, out of pocket and not covered medical expenses, as well as living expenses is not totally covered. Current sources and what income he does have will not pay his bills by far.  
 
We need all the help we can get to raise funds.  His family has been wonderful, dedicating much time and care-taking.  And even with the tremendous fatigue that comes with cancer treatment, Karl has done his best to continue working to pay his bills.

story:
Hello my friends,

For some of you who may not know us, my name is Thanh and my wife’s name is Jennifer. We’ve been happily married for over 9 years and we would like to ask for your help. 3 years ago Jennifer developed an illness called IgA nephropathy http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0001500/. This illness attacked Jennifer’s kidneys and now she needs a kidney transplant. While waiting for over 2 years for a kidney, Jennifer has had over 20 surgeries ranging from minor procedures putting in a dialysis catheter to heart surgery to remove a tumor. I do hemo-dialysis (filtering blood) for Jennifer 6 days a week for the last 2 years. Jennifer was a hygienist but due to her illness her work place released her last year before Christmas. So she has been unemployed for a year now. Because of this I work somewhere between 10-12 hours a day to pay the bills and sometimes this isn’t enough.

On New Years day of this year, Jennifer and I got a phone call from KU Medical Center and our prayers were answered when they told us there was a kidney for her. UNFORTUNATELY, the day before, Jennifer had a fever of 101.7 degrees. Because of this, they gave the kidney to someone else who was not sick. Due to her immune system being weakened from medicines related to the surgery, she could die if she proceeded with the transplant while being ill. Currently Jennifer is taking medicines to get better so when they call us again, we’ll be ready to go to Kansas City, MO. Jennifer could get a kidney this weekend coming up or next month; it’s hard to tell. When she does get a kidney though, our journey will have just began. We will have to take a 3 hour drive to Kansas City, MO where Jennifer will be in the hospital for 7 days for pre and post surgery. Then we are required to live in Kansas City (be close to KU Medical Center) for another 7 days just in case there is any rejection of the new kidney. After the 14 days, we will need to come back to Kansas City once every week for one month, and then every 6 months for the next couple of years.

Jennifer and I need your help. I will need to take off of work for a significant time, the cost of the previous trips to KU (for testing), the cost of this trip, future trip for her new kidney, and the initial cost of immune-suppressant drugs and I don’t think we will be able to make ends meet. Even though I have a good job, that pays better than average, good insurance, and we have been saving a little bit of money but we’re still going to come up short.

Overall, we need over $4,000 but Indego charges 9% if you don’t meet your goal so we’re hoping to ask for $4,000. Just so you guys have an idea of what your contribution will be helping us with here is a list of SOME of the cost we’ll need to pay for.

Money needed to pay for bills for the month due to me not working. $2,300.00
7 days in a motel/hotel near the Hospital. $600.00
Transportation cost for all the trips to Kansas City, 6 trips. $475.00 
Meals while in Kansas City for 14 days. $500.00
Initial Immuno-suppressant drugs. $250.00

When Jennifer gets a kidney it would mean so much to us if you could help us out, we understand that money is tight for everyone but even if you could give $5 it can go along way with as many friends that we have. If you can also please get our story out there and help us as much as you can. We love you all and thank you so much for helping us.  

Sincerely,
Thanh and Jennifer

story:
Our Story

Rayn Josephine Marie Nigro was born on October 1, 1994.  She has lived in Johnsonville NY for her entire life.  She has attended Hoosic Valley schooling, where she has participated in many clubs and activities.  She partakes in Foreign Language club, SADD, and she is part of the Yearbook staff.
 
Where Rayn's time was mostly spent, however, was being part of a sports team.  Regardless of the season Rayn participated in a sport.  During the fall it was Volleyball, where she would frequently be high scorer, and had the most kills.  During the winter Rayn was part of the basketball team.  During her junior year, her team worked hard and became the New York State Champions.  Her free time during the Spring was occupied by the Hoosic Valley track and field team and field team.  She was Wasaren League Champion for High Jump, but she also did Long Jump, Pole Vault, and Triple Jump.
 
This is Rayn's senior year of high school and the time to make decisions as to which school she will attend next fall was swiftly approaching.  Upon the end of the Volleyball season, where Rayn's team lost in the semi-finals of the Sectional games, she was offered an athletic scholarship to SUNY Canton. 
 
Rayn was unfamiliar with this college so she and her friend Tiffany scheduled a tour of the college.  They skipped school and left for the college visit on November 28th planning to return on the next day, November 29th. During the visit she attended several Criminal Justice classes, got the tour of the campus, and played with the Girls Volley ball team. 
 
When she awoke in the morning she and Tiffany packed up and got on the road to make it home in time for basketball practice that afternoon. On the way back Rayn got tired and allowed Tiffany to drive.  She proceeded to nap while Tiffany continued to drive them home.  When Rayn woke up she told Tiffany that she was alright to drive again, so she told Tiffany to get off at the next exit.  As they were pulling off the exit ramp, they lost control of the vehicle and the car rolled onto its side, the car hit a guardrail and proceeded to roll down a hill, completing 8 rotations of the vehicle.  A car driving the other direction saw the car rolling down the hill and immediately called the police while pulling a U-turn.
 
The first sheriff on the scene instantly knew that Rayn would need helicopter assistance to Albany Medical Center.  She was rushed into the ER for an emergency CT Scan.  It showed the Doctors that she had small amounts of bleeding on the brain.  This is what made Rayn remain unconscious.  She also had a break in the Right Clavicle, and a small fracture on the tip of her tail bone.  Rayn spent the first night in the Neurological Observation unit.  The next afternoon she was transported to the Trauma unit. After one or two good days the hospital wanted to release Rayn home.  Several people, including Nurses (who will remain Nameless), did not think that Rayn was ready to be Discharged.  Her brother Gage called the Brain Injury Association Of New York and hassled the people there to get Rayn into a Rehabilitation Center.  That is where Rayn is now, at the SunnyView Rehabilitation Center.

What We Need

Seeing as the driver of the vehicle was Unlicensed and not covered by Rayn's insurance, the car insurance company is only willing to pay for up to $100,000. The break down that our family received of the pricing is as follows:
  • Helicopter Ride: $150,000
  • One night in the Neurological Obsevation Unit: $50,000
  • Six days in Trauma @ $30,000 a day: $180,000
  • Six shots of Morphine @$2,500 per shot: $15,000

This brings the total to $395,000, subtract the $100,000 from the insurance company and that $295,000.  This doesn't include the transportation to the Rehab Center, the multiple X-rays and MRI's she received, the medications for nausea and pain on top of morphine, the rehabilitation center costs, or the months of therapy in the near future.

So as you can see this is a huge financial burden our family has taken on, and we are asking for help from friends, family, community members, anyone really.  We are setting our goal to $50,000 for now, this is to avoid the fee's from this site, but in all reality we need much much more.  Anything you or your families can do will help our family and it will be greatly appreciated.  Please share this link to all social media sites and anywhere else you can think to post it.  Our family appreciates anything you can do.  Thanks

story:
WE HAVE HOPE FOR TAVISH'S FUTURE BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP! 

Tavish Kliewer is an amazing 12 year old boy who is severely affected by autism. Right now, Tav is going through one of the hardest times of his life and needs help.

Over the past few months, there has been a significant increase in self-injurious and aggressive behaviours that are getting dangerous; both to himself and to those around him. As a result, Tav's Mom and Dad have sought out help in the form of intensive behavioural therapy designed to address these types of issues.

The problem is that intensive, targeted, proven ABA based interventions are very, very expensive and funding is almost impossible to access. So, that's where you come in! This page will serve to help facilitate the process of raising the funds required to give this incredible little boy a chance at a better quality of life. 

How the money will be used:

Two qualified and experienced therapists (experts in the field) have been retained to deliver the therapy. Their services will be paid with funds raised.

Tav's parents and therapy team will need to purchase equipment and supplies to use in the course of treatment. These will be paid for with funds raised. 

Tav will need follow-up sessions and his school and centre staff will have to be trained to maintain his gains and ensure that he continues to be successful. This will be paid for with funds raised. 

And finally, as Tavish is non-verbal, learning a new and comprehensive communication system will be of utmost importance to ensure success. He will need access to augmentative communication software, potentially new hardware and people trained around him to continue to help him learn to better communicate. This will be paid for with funds raised. 

Our eventual goal is to raise $20,000 to offset the costs. However, we are starting smaller so that we can get started as soon as possible. And rest assured that every cent raised will be spent on Tavish's treatment and accounted for, should you be interested in seeing a break down. 

Please help us achieve this goal. And thank you. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you.

The Kliewer Family

story:
ShapeLoggers

The idea and how it began

I, a 20 years old Software Engineering student from Germany, am sports and social media interested for quite a few years.

At one day (end of 2012) the idea to build a new platform to combine these interests came up in my head (must have been in the shower or other places where you get great ideas). I liked it and started to plan this project on my own first. 

But I didn't just like it because it combines my interests! It was more the feeling of creating something that could help many ambitious, dedicated and focussed athletes all over the world. Do you remember the time where you just started lifting weights, eating healthy and working your ass of to reach your dream body?

If you do so, think of the load of different information you got from the internet, books, friends, ominous trainers and other people. That was not always right, was it? While planning ShapeLoggers I always thought about making things easier. I took the main components of successful fitness and bodybuilding (training, nutrition and recovery) and designed tools to track, log, plan and document them. So you always see where you are for example at your training at the moment, how much calories you eat and how your body reacts on what you are doing!

It took a while to do a bit of research, plan and implement the planned functions. I worked whole nights (yeah... sleeping is important for fitness), before university, during university, after university, on holiday and finally on 19th July 2013 the first stable BETA of ShapeLoggers was released under a "de"-domain.

From then I worked on spreading ShapeLoggers to the German athletes and implementing new features and functions daily. But the big problem that I had to face, and always do, is that I am alone, have no money for advertising and spreading ShapeLoggers and do not even earn something from it (quite the opposite).


The turning point

I want to change that now with this Crowdfunding project and I need YOUR help to go on with ShapeLoggers. I don't want it to be just another unimportant portal on the web because I designed it to help people and combine every possible tool for fitness, bodybuilding and other sports where you lift weights.

This thinking leads me to the following points which are not doable if there is no money for them, and for which I need your support:

  • Offering more than one language (which is currently only German) (350€ for new law-required texts per language)
  • Buying more domains (70 €/year)
  • Hire more webspace, bigger databases and stronger server in general (150 €/year)
  • Advertising on the Internet and, if possible, in huge gym-companies (2000€ once)
  • A lawyer to advocate me in legal aspects (one time: 349€ + 480€/year)
  • External & feed-required programming libraries and programms for some new functions (about 80-120€ once) 
  • For new functions in general
  • ShapeLoggers' internal awards where you can compete with other athletes and win prices (120€/year for prices)
  • One very big thing: an Android and iOS-App (Apple Dev-License: 80€/year)
  • Launch a shop with merchandise (1500€ seed capital)

As you can see, the main point is "getting bigger" to reach more people, not only in Germany like it's the case now, but in THE WHOLE WORLD.

4100€ fixed costs and 900€ per year, so this can survive about 4 years until the shop will hopefully cover all yearly costs. 


Current functions of ShapeLoggers

To show you what I already achieved without funding, I list up all current functions of ShapeLoggers here:

  • Training & nutrition plan editors
  • Saving training and nutrition plans of other users in your favorites
  • Logging training & nutrition with plans or free editors
  • Getting training & nutrition statistics
  • Inserting your shape represented by circumferences, pictures, weight, bodyfat, description, YouTube-Video
  • generate before/after-comparisons from your shapes
  • Statistics about your weight, bodyfat and body development (more to come of course)
  • Titles & Badges to be displayed behind your name and in your profile
  • normal and Body-Awards where you can compete in several disciplines with other users
  • Photos and photo albums, Videos (linked from YouTube)
  • Shopping list generator (from nutrition plan)
  • macronutrient-calculator
  • body fat calculation with 3-wrinkles-method & navy-method
  • 1 Repetition calculator
  • Training partner search
  • caloric requirements calculator
  • Food, Exercise and supplement database (extended from everyone & administrated by me)
  • Privacy settings: select if a content or your profile is public, for you & your friends or just private
  • Groups, private messages, friends administration, settings for your account
  • Comment, rate and share everything
  • Export everything to pdf-file
  • filterable newsfeed to post to, like posts and comment
  • Notification center and live-popup notifications (like Facebook)

Some impressions from screenshots (of course, currently only in German):

Training statistics for deadlift with stiff legs from 1 until 20 reps

Free training log editor (exercises, reps, weight, weight unit, increase/lower/leave the weight next time)

Already saved nutrition logs

Nutrition statistics

generated before & after comparison out of 2 (example-) shapes, of course not me ;-)

generated shopping list out of a nutrition plan and number of days

already saved training logs

body weight development graph



My request to you

So, my message to you is: Please support ShapeLoggers and profit from the available perks of this campaign and of course the project itself!

If you want to support it outside of Indiegogo, visit the brand new English speaking ShapeLoggers facebook page or the German ShapeLoggers facebook page and leave a like if you want.

Thank you!

ShapeLoggers' internal awards where you can compete with other athletes and win prices (120€/year for prices)
One very big thing: an Android and iOS-App (Apple Dev-License: 80€/year)
Launch a shop with merchandise (1500€ seed capital)

As you can see, the main point is "getting bigger" to reach more people, not only in Germany like it's the case now, but in THE WHOLE WORLD.
4100€ fixed costs and 900€ per year, so this can survive about 4 years until the shop will hopefully cover all yearly costs. 



Current functions of ShapeLoggers
To show you what I already achieved without funding, I list up all current functions of ShapeLoggers here:


Training & nutrition plan editors
Saving training and nutrition plans of other users in your favorites
Logging training & nutrition with plans or free editors
Getting training & nutrition statistics
Inserting your shape represented by circumferences, pictures, weight, bodyfat, description, YouTube-Video
generate before/after-comparisons from your shapes
Statistics about your weight, bodyfat and body development (more to come of course)
Titles & Badges to be displayed behind your name and in your profile
normal and Body-Awards where you can compete in several disciplines with other users
Photos and photo albums, Videos (linked from YouTube)
Shopping list generator (from nutrition plan)
macronutrient-calculator
body fat calculation with 3-wrinkles-method & navy-method
1 Repetition calculator
Training partner search
caloric requirements calculator
Food, Exercise and supplement database (extended from everyone & administrated by me)
Privacy settings: select if a content or your profile is public, for you & your friends or just private
Groups, private messages, friends administration, settings for your account
Comment, rate and share everything
Export everything to pdf-file
filterable newsfeed to post to, like posts and comment
Notification center and live-popup notifications (like Facebook)

Some impressions from screenshots (of course, currently only in German):




Training statistics for deadlift with stiff legs from 1 until 20 reps

Free training log editor (exercises, reps, weight, weight unit, increase/lower/leave the weight next time)

Already saved nutrition logs

Nutrition statistics

generated before & after comparison out of 2 (example-) shapes, of course not me ;-)

generated shopping list out of a nutrition plan and number of days

already saved training logs

body weight development graph


My request to you
So, my message to you is: Please support ShapeLoggers and profit from the available perks of this campaign and of course the project itself!
If you want to support it outside of Indiegogo, visit the brand new English speaking ShapeLoggers facebook page or the German ShapeLoggers facebook page and leave a like if you want.
Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Garrett Andrews is a 15 year-old living in Cartersville, GA who was born with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. This campaign has been created to help raise funds his family so desperately needs in order to make their home handicap accessible. There are two immediate needs: 

-A remodel of the front doorway

- A remodel of the bathroom in order to fit a handicap accessible shower

This disorder typically causes servere weakness requiring the use of a wheelchair. As much as Garrett has fought using a wheelchair full-time, he does have to use it for mobility at school and most daily activities. He now needs upgrades to his home to improve his quality of life.

Garrett is a great kid with such a huge heart and his extended family is trying to raise some money to help off-set the costs of the immediate need to upgrade his home for a little sense of ease in his day to day life. The current bathroom is too dangerous and he risks falling and seriously injuring himself and his parents have a difficult time lifting him in and out of the tub.  Also, Garrett cannot enter his house with his wheelchair, so the front of his house needs to be remodeled with a wheelchair ramp.

Despite this debilitating disease, through extreme strength and determination, Garrett has managed to start high school even though he was told early on that he would likely be wheelchair bound by eight years old - but school is very tough for him because of his disability. He was often bullied and still cannot participate in many activities his classmates may take for granted. The staff of Cartersville School System has stepped up at any time the family has voiced concerns in order to make his school experience more positive. In particular, Stephanie Ericks, Nick Bridges and Jessica Bunce (his teachers) have been very helpful.

The emotional pain is hard, but Garrett has never known a day in his life without excruciating physical pain.  His doctors report that his pain level has always been off the charts. His family is asking the community to band together so they can do whatever they can to make his life more comfortable. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $20,000 to renovate the front of Garrett's home to make it wheelchair accessible as well as building a shower that can accommodate his wheelchair. These changes will offer Garrett the freedom and independence any teenage boy deserves. However, we are setting the goal at $10,000 to ensure we meet it and can get at least one project completed.

We have lots of great perks to donating such as jewelry, Braves tickets, a signed football from Mark Richt and much more. So please take a look and give what you can!

National Muscular Dystrophy Awareness Month

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy prevents the production of dystrophin which is the normal protein in muscle and typically appears between the age of two and six affecting 1 out of 3500 boys.  Because of this, muscle weakness can begin as early as age three, first affecting the muscles of the hips, pelvic area, thighs and shoulders, and later the skeletal (voluntary) muscles in the arms, legs and trunk. The weakness typically causes clumsiness, frequent falling, an unusual gait and general weakness. Most patients with Duchennes require a wheelchair.

By the early teens, the heart and respiratory muscles also are affected. Sadly most do not make it past their early 20s because the muscles in the heart and lungs are no longer capable of functioning to support life.

There is currently no cure for DMD.  It is a terminal condition. 

With this month being Muscular Dystrophy awareness month, in addition to fundraising, Garrett's family hopes to raise awareness and understanding about this disease. 

"My son and our family hopes that if more people are aware of this diagnosis, these kids will be treated kinder or more normal," Garrett's mom explains. "Go up and speak with children in wheelchairs.  Most kids just love some kind of positive contact.  It may be a little different in some instances due to some children just do not get the socialization they need.  So please take time to share a few minutes with special needs children.  It will make a huge difference in their lives."

More About Garrett

Garrett loves hunting and fishing which is typical for kids in Cartersville and North Georgia. His family is comprised of fisherman and hunters, so he has been surrounded by this his whole life. He loves Country Music and enjoys video games.  He doesn't have a lot of strength in his hands, so video games can be a bit tricky. 

As he has recently turned fifteen, seeing his classmates and cousins all learning to drive and getting their permits, he would like to be able to drive as well.  Even if he could get a learner's license, his family - even if they all pooled our money together - could not afford a vehicle outfitted for his disabilities.  

A friend of the family, Russell, realized how much Garrett enjoyed the outdoors and driving.  Russell located a second hand golf cart which the owner donated. Garrett really enjoys driving it around.  It allows him freedom around the yard, coming and going to his grandparents next door and most of all to and from the lake to fish.  The camouflage golf cart helps him get around without feeling disabled.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute financially, please share Garrett's story! Please help get the word out and allow others the opportunity to band together as a community to help this family in need. Most importantly, please remember Garrett and his family in your prayers. Thank you for any consideration you may offer to this very worthy cause.

story:
UPDATE: Thank you for helping us reach our initial goal. We can now move onto raising money to develop our online community.

Childhood illness and obesity has more than tripled over the past few decades. Our children are exposed to more and more chemicals. Many of them toxic, the large majority of them untested. While we don't know all of the long-term effects, we do know that it's making them sick and cutting their life expectancy.

Cancer Schmancer's Detox Your Home in-school program hopes to reverse that trend. The steps a child takes to reduce cancer risk are the same as those to reduce a host of childhood illnesses like obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. 

And here's a shocking fact. Only 10% of cancers are caused by genetics. You have 90% control over whether you get sick or not. 

We plan on bringing this message to every school in the nation, teaching kids how to avoid harmful toxins IN their food, what they put ON their skin, and AROUND their homes. We will also teach strategies for healthy eating, exercise, and stress-reduction. 

The habits we develop when we're young last a lifetime. Kids who follow Cancer Schmancer's guidelines will be less likely to develop cancer and other chronic disease. We want to give children longer lives of higher quality.

Healthy kids grow into healthy parents who raise even healthier kids and so on. Imagine the impact. Our hope is to wipe out cancer in the next generation. It may sound like an impossible dream, but who got anywhere dreaming small?

Our Leader: Fran Drescher

You may know Fran Drescher as the star of The Nanny, but you may not know that she is a uterine cancer survivor. She founded the Cancer Schmancer Movement so that what happened to her won't happen to other people. That's why she's sounding the alarm about carcinogens in our food, cosmetics, and home cleaning products.

Perhaps if Fran had known what she'd been exposing herself to when she was a teenager, she wouldn't have had the cancer and the radical hysterectomy that saved her life. At the time, she was in love with a man and planning on having children with him. But you don't get to choose the cards life deals you. You only get to choose how to play them. Fran decided to turn her pain into purpose. She may not have been able to have children with the man she loved, but she can help you protect your kids. That's why this program means so much to her.

So much so that Fran is putting her money where her famous voice is. She'll match donations up to $25,000. Donate $1, and she'll make it $2. She's doing half the lifting. Will you lift the other half?

What We Need & Why

Before we go to the entire country, we need to develop the pilot program. The $10,000 we're raising will go toward the pilot launch on Earth Day 2015 at two schools in the Los Angeles area. Following the in-school presentation, students are encouraged to learn more on their own with takeaway projects that they can do both at school and at home with their parents.

We will then make revisions based on the pilot schools' feedback before we expand the program to other schools across the United States. The program may be led by any adult or group of adults -- school administrator, teacher or parent. We will also make the curriculum available to parents who home school.  

Funds that exceed our goal will be used for this expansion and go toward developing our online community and a mobile app that children can use when out shopping or at a restaurant to identify toxins in food and products they're considering purchasing.

*Proceeds over $10,000 fund these projects

About Cancer Schmancer

Cancer Schmancer fills a unique space among cancer organizations. A large part of our mission is Prevention. The best way to prevent cancer is not to get it in the first place, which is the purpose of our Detox Your Home Prevention program. We help you identify and get rid of toxins in your environment, empowering you to reduce your risk.

Another part of our mission is Early Detection. Get regular screenings and learn the warning signs and whispers of cancers likely to affect you so that you catch it in the early stages when it’s most preventable. We are extremely proud of Our Fran Van program, which offers free mammograms & other screenings to women who otherwise might not have the resources or access.

The last part of our mission is Policy Change. We use our voice on Capitol Hill to enact legislation that protects consumers from harmful chemicals and encourages health education. Fran is a Public Diplomacy Envoy for Women's Health Issues and was instrumental in the passage of the Gynecologic Cancer Education & Awareness Act. Our cuurent initiative is the bipartisan Carcinogen-FREE Label Act.

What You Get

Your or Loved One's Selfie on our Website ($10)

Cancer Schmancer Tote Bag ($20)

Made from Recycled Materials

 *Ships only to continental U.S.

Twank You from @FranDrescher ($25)

Cancer Schmancer T-shirt ($35)

 *Ships only to continental U.S.

Detox Your Home Starter Kit from Healthy Home Company ($50)

Retail Value $70.85

Ask Fran Anything on Skype ($50)

Space is limited

Cancer Schmancer DVD Collection ($100)

 *Ships only to continental U.S.

Donors Club ($100)

Limit 500

Fran Drescher Records Your Voice Mail Greeting ($500)

Detox Your Home Official Sponsor ($5,000)

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the resources to contribute. Try some of these other ways to help:

  • Share this campaign on Facebook
  • Share this campaign on Twitter
  • Throw a Detox Your Home Party for your family & friends
  • Share your personal story about how cancer affected your life

Thank You So Much! xo-F
